abstract: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.
snippet: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.
lead_paragraph: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.

headline.main: Plain Talk From Judge Weighing Merrill Case
headline.print_headline: Plain Talk From Judge Weighing Merrill Case

abstract: Jed S. Rakoff, a U.S. District Court judge in Manhattan, is tussling with the S.E.C. and Bank of America, which will both file reports to him Monday detailing who knew what about $3.6 billion in bonuses paid out by Merrill Lynch last year.
snippet: Jed S. Rakoff, a U.S. District Court judge in Manhattan, is tussling with the S.E.C. and Bank of America, which will both file reports to him Monday detailing who knew what about $3.6 billion in bonuses paid out by Merrill Lynch last year.
lead_paragraph: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions, Louise Story wrote in The New York Times.

headline.main: Plain Talk From Judge Weighing Merrill Case

abstract: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.
snippet: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.
lead_paragraph: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.

headline.main: Bank Case on Bonuses Shifts Focus to Lawyers
headline.print_headline: Bank Case On Bonuses Shifts Focus To Lawyers

abstract: Bank of America, in a court filing, said it acted properly when it did not disclose details about bonuses paid at Merrill Lynch in advance of a shareholder vote.
snippet: Bank of America, in a court filing, said it acted properly when it did not disclose details about bonuses paid at Merrill Lynch in advance of a shareholder vote.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after its deal to purchase Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is still on the defensive.

headline.main: Bank of America Defends Its Merrill Settlement
